Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Specialized high resolution imaging system for rapid batch screening of aflatoxin in corn
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project will be commercially deployable equipment for screening, detecting, and removing aflatoxin contaminated corn from the global food supply. Exposure to aflatoxin, a dangerous fungal carcinogen, has been linked to liver cancer, childhood stunting, illness and death in humans and animals, and major economic losses for farmers and grain handlers in the U.S. and globally. Rapid batch screening equipment will expand the capacity of the grain industry to test more corn for aflatoxin contamination and minimize the high sampling error that currently plagues the aflatoxin testing process and risks greater contamination exposure downstream. In addition to batch screening equipment, opportunities also exist to develop handheld devices to identify contaminated corn in the field, and continuous flow optical sorters, deployed at grain handling and food processing facilities, to remove the contaminated corn and protect the market value of the healthy grain. The goal is to 1) Increase revenue for farmers in the U.S. and globally; 2) Protect the food supply and reduce the risks of greater contamination exposure for farmers, grain handlers, and consumers; and 3) Protect feed supply and improve productivity of livestock.

This STTR Phase I project proposes to demonstrate the feasibility of a specialized high resolution imaging system for rapid batch screening of aflatoxin in corn. The research team will build the prototype unit and image processing software with the patented algorithm for detection of aflatoxin in corn, integrated with a high resolution, dual-camera system. With existing chemical tests for aflatoxin detection, it is difficult for grain handlers to test larger samples or every truck without causing major delays in operations. The key technical hurdle for rapid batch screening with this technology is reliable imaging analysis of sufficient size samples, screened fast enough for the imaging system to fit into commercial grain handling operations without disruption. By screening hundreds of corn samples with the rapid batch screening prototype unit, the team will validate device accuracy of >95% true positive and true negative for detection of corn contaminated with aflatoxin, consistently across contamination ranges and proportions, at a processing speed fast enough to be deployed by commercial grain handlers on every truckload.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Aflatoxin, a dangerous fungal carcinogen, affects 25% of the world's food crops, including corn, the most widely produced grain in the world. Exposure to aflatoxin has been linked to liver cancer, childhood stunting, illness and death in humans, pets and livestock, as well as major economic losses for farmers and grain handlers in the U.S. and globally.

Secure Food Solutions (SFS) received funding from the National Science Foundation Small Business Technology Transfer Phase 1 program (2017) to demonstrate the feasibility of a specialized high resolution imaging system for rapid batch screening of aflatoxin contamination in corn. The SFS team, led by Chris Ramezanpour (Co-PI) collaborated with Dr. Haibo Yao (Co-PI) of Mississippi State University, and Drs. Jeffrey Cary and Kanniah Rajasekaran of USDA-ARS (advisers). Software development and integration with the imaging system was performed at MSU's research facility at Stennis Space Center, as was the screening of corn samples. Chemical analysis of the corn samples for aflatoxin was conducted at the USDA Southern Regional Research Center. The research team developed image processing software based on a patented (US Patent: 8,563,934 B2) fluorescence-based spectral imaging technology to detect corn contaminated with aflatoxin. This software was linked to a high resolution, dual camera array to demonstrate the technology's ability to automate high speed, accurate and non-destructive screening of corn for the presence of aflatoxin.  The desired goal was to achieve > 95% true positive and true negative detection rates for aflatoxin contamination in corn, with commercial samples, at processing speeds fast enough to fit into commercial grain handling operations without disruption.

The results of the original research were based on screening and testing over 500 samples of whole kernel corn from commercial batches. The system demonstrated rapid and non-destructive screening capacity, with 74.83% true positive rate, and 57.36% true negative rate. When screening was done 'by sample' false positive and false negative errors from a single kernel biased characterization of the entire sample. Because these mischaracterizations of a sample could bias an entire lot, it was determined that the system was not well-suited for commercial batch screening of corn samples. However, in the process of this research the team was also able to analyze a 'per kernel' screening approach, the method used in high volume optical sorting applications. During added Phase 1 research (Jan – Feb 2018), with 70 samples of white kernel food-grade corn, which contained some of the most contaminated kernels of any batch tested, 'per kernel' screening with the imaging system demonstrated accuracy rates of 57.14% true positive, and 99.97% true negative. The true negative rate was exceptionally high. False negatives affected the true positive rate and were believed to be the result of the fungal infection acting only on one side of the kernel, and that side not facing the lighting and camera.

A multi-pass 'per kernel' optical sorting system (used in the color sorting of nuts), which rejects suspicious kernels after each pass, could significantly raise the true positive rate of the system by improving the chance that both sides of a potentially false negative kernel are screened. Based on the 'per kernel' detection accuracy of the imaging system in the added Phase 1 research, a three-pass sorting system would have an overall true positive rate of 92.13%, and true negative rate of 99.91% - sufficient for commercial application.

The overall processing speed of the system was 0.69 seconds, and consisted primarily of exposure time for image capture with the camera under UV light. Increasing the light intensity from the UV lights, as well as decreasing the distance of the light source(s) from the target, could decrease this exposure time significantly, and potentially increase the sorting volume to 3.7 tons/hour per 12-inch wide conveyor (per pass). Most sorters on the market increase throughput capacity by expanding the number of conveyors in the module. At 3.7 tons per hour per conveyor, a five-conveyor sorter, not uncommon for industrial purposes, would be capable of screening over 18 tons per hour (per pass) – sufficient for commercial application.

The results from Phase 1 research have led to Phase 2 proposal plans for prototype development and commercialization of a multi-pass optical sorter integrated with the imaging system, to enable rapid screening and removal of corn contaminated with aflatoxin, without destroying clean healthy kernels. The benefits of rapid, non-destructive screening of the entire lot, enabled by these high volume optical sorters, include: (1) Removing aflatoxin, which can occur at high levels in a small amount of corn in a lot, while protecting the healthy kernels in the lot; (2) Protecting the food and feed supply by reducing the risk of exposure to contamination and dangerous health effects associated with acute and chronic aflatoxin consumption; and (3) Increasing revenue and export opportunities for farmers in the U.S. and globally.
